24.heading: Bruce.

25.heading: Bruce.
25.title: "The Children in the Glass Tubes"
25.author: art: Lily Renee
notes: Introduction of Bruce (brain transplanted to a Voltaman's body), Bonnie, Robin; villains are the Voltamen (this is the first story in which they with Latin syntax speak), Prince Guth (introduced and dies; body used as receptacle for Bruce's brain).
Data from Lou Mougin via the Grand Comics Database Project.

26.heading: Bruce.
26.title: "Denizens of the Ancient Subway"
26.author: art: Lily Renee
notes: Appearances of Bruce, Bonnie, and Robin; villains are the Voltamen, and the Taomen and their Chief who are all introduced and all die; introduction and death of a professor.
Data from Lou Mougin via the Grand Comics Database Project.

27.heading: Bruce.
27.title: "The Hypnosphere"
27.author: art: Lily Renee
notes: Appearance of Bruce; villains are Voltamen, and Lorento (who is introduced and dies).

28.heading: Bruce.

188.heading: Les Brumes Aveugles--Miscellanea.
188.title: "Druillet & Spiegelman Take Grand Prizes"
188.author: by Jean-Paul Jennequin
188.appears_in: p. 19 in The Comics Journal, no. 121 (Apr. 1988).
notes: Lists the awards at the 15th Angoulême festival. The grand prize went to Philippe Druillet. The Alfreds were for best album: Les Survivants de l'Ombre (Blanc-Dumont & Harlé) ; best foreign album: Maus (Spiegelman) ; best first album: Le Soleil des Loups (Arthur Qwak, Ralph, & Gonnort) ; best album for young people: L'Expedition Maudite (De Moor) ; best children's album: Les Brumes Aveugles (Gine & Convard) ; best uses of comics in advertising (Alfred de la Communication): Pas de SIDA pour Miss Poireau (Mandryka & Moliterni) ; best fanzine: Sortez la Chienne.
Other non-Alfred prizes are also listed.
